data.title: Terri Hooley

data.text:
No better tune.

Lauren Martin

Can you give us a little bit of a background about that particular track, and its story for your life, because itâs tied into quite a pivotal moment in your young life.

Terri Hooley

Itâs very funny. I used it at the opening of Good Vibrations, the film. Iâm a huge Hank Williams fan, and a lot of young people are coming up and asking me to play it, which is great. Hank Williams was a great singer-songwriter, and most of his work was done in three years, and he died early. He left a legacy, just everybodyâ¦ loads of people have recorded, and are still recording Hank Williams songs.

Itâs my first musical memory, because at the age of six, I lived in East Belfast in a place called Garnerville estate, in a pre-fab bungalow, and I got my eye shot out. When the ambulance came, and they put bandages around my two eyes, and it was a lovely sunny day and I could see the light, and they were putting me into the ambulance, and I was thinking, âThese guys are crazy. I could walk in the ambulance myself.â All I could think of was Hank Williamsâs âI Saw the Lightâ.

So, the BBC, many, many years later, phoned me up and went, âIs it true, the grandfather of punk is a big Hank Williams fan?â I said, âI absolutely am.â They said, âWould you like to come in and talk â itâs his birthday tomorrow?â I went, âIâd love to.â I told that story, and a woman got in touch with the BBC and wanted to know how to get in touch with me, because they didnât know where Iâd first heard it. It turned out that her aunties ran a guest house on Botanic Avenue, and my grandfather used to go around and collect on a Friday, money â donations for the church, because we were running a guest house we didnât go then. I think even Gene Vincent once stayed in that guest house, but Iâm not quite sure about that.

Anyway, one Friday I went around and they put on that record, and I begged them and begged them and begged them to play it again and again and again. I found out eventually where I first heard it. Stuart Baileyâs sitting there â just back from Nashville â gave me his fatherâs 78 copy for a Christmas present there. Itâs one of the few things Iâm allowed to put up on the wall in my girlfriendâs house. After eight years, I was allowed to put up two awards, and Stuartâs 78â¦ Iâve got a foot in the door now.

Lauren Martin

You finally got a copy of it to hang and put on your wall.

Terri Hooley

Itâs just beautiful to see it, and itâs in really good condition. It just reminds me ofâ¦ I used to go to peopleâs houses, especially in the â60s. I love all kinds of music. Iâm very passionate about music. Iâm not a musical snob â far from it. Everybody thinks Iâmâ¦ I love some of the most ridiculous records in the world.

I used to go, and all these girlsâ¦ It was the â60s, and it was the Stones, it was the Beatles, it was a really exciting time. Iâd be pulling out their dadsâ Charlie Parker albums, or Paganini, and Nina Simone and Ella Fitzgerald. âWhy you playing my mom and dadâs record collection?â Itâs just, I was always really interested to read the covers, to see who recorded it â fanatical, really. I was a bit of a record collectorâs nerd at the time. Iâm not so much now, but I was definitely then.

Lauren Martin

You were quite the record collector nerd from early on. Did you get that from your father?

Terri Hooley

No. The greatest thing aboutâ¦ We livedâ¦ We were more or less very, very poor, and everybody was in those days. The first record I ever actually owned, the day I became a record collector, I have still got; unbelievable â three divorces, been burnt out â and it was a Summer County [margarine] free flip-flop record. The guy came down the street, and he put one through our letter box, and I ran after him and askedâ¦ I begged him for one, and he gave it to me.

I knew my brother, even though he didnât really want it, he wouldnât let me have the other record. He was a bit mean, actually. I donât want to talk ill of the dead, but he was a right bastard. I hid it in the airing cupboard, under the towels. For months, I just would go in and lock myself in the bathroom and read all the words.

I invented a gameâ¦ It was Terri Hooley, Stuart Bailey, and Iâd count all the âTsâ on the record, and you got a point for each âTâ, and the âSâ for Stuart, and then see who would win. Iâd do this with all my friends. One day, a friend asked me, would I give him a hand with a chair to go around to his auntieâs house, and she had a record player. I heard it for the first time. It was, âSwinging on a Garden Gate,â by Humphrey Lyttelton, who was a great jazz musician, because jazz was the music of my youth.

When I heard it for the first time I thought, âJesus, this is just wonderful,â and that was my very first record that I ever got, and I didnât even have to steal it. David Holmes, famous DJ, he wrote in my bookâ¦

The original text was, âTerri gave me all these â60s soul records, and I think he stole them from somebody who was in prison.â

âDavid, what are you going on about? I might steal your girlfriend, I might steal your drink, I might steal your drugs, but Iâd never steal your record collection; no way.â

Lauren Martin

Even from early on, music was such a massive part of your life, but I know that as well as records, radio was a big part of your life.

Terri Hooley

Yeah.

Lauren Martin

I know that your dad bought you your first radio when you were six years old; he brought it back from a trip?

Terri Hooley

No, my dad was very left, and my mom was very Christian. My father was English, and they met during the war, and my grandfather didnât like my dad much at all, neither did my uncles. My grandfather pleaded with my mom, the day that they got married, not to marry him. He was a real leftie, and they were all Orange.

My mom married my dad, and she went to England and she didnât like it, so she left and came back home. I lived a lot at my grandparentsâ house, which was great, because they had a big piano, and I was in love with my aunties. I was a bit of a mommyâs boy, hanging on to my momâs apron strings. Everybody would sit around and sing, around the piano and all, and perform, and it was just magical.

We went to the Garnerville, and then my mom and dad would go out to their Labour party meetings at night, and Iâd sneak out of bed and listen to Radio Luxembourg, fanatically, and hear all this wonderful music, and American Forces overseas, to hear the blues and the soul. My father went to Sweden on a trade union gig, and he brought me back my first transistor radio. That was heaven to me, to be able to hear music anywhere.

It was just fantastic. I did have what was called a crystal set, which you used the frame of the bed as an aerial, and it was old ex-army headphones, and it was very limited. But to be able to walk about, carrying and listening to music, was just magical to me.

Lauren Martin

It may seem a bit hard to believe, with a lot of the younger people in the room, but it really was, in a lot of respects, the only way to hear music, was through the radio â through Radio Luxembourg and Radio Caroline. What sort of records were you exposed to? I would imagine, not having that much choice, what you were exposed to you either absolutely loved or absolutely hated. What kind of records were really catching you from a young age, listening to the radio?

Terri Hooley

I remember listening to American overseas broadcasts. It was really for the American troops in Germany. Iâm just back from San Francisco, and I heard this record one nightâ¦ I didnât know who it was, I didnât catch who it was. It was called âSan Francisco Bay Blues.â

âIâve got the blues for my baby down by the San Francisco Bay, ocean linerâs gone so far away. I didnât mean to treat her so bad, best girl I ever had.â It was just an amazing record to me, and it took me a while to find out who it was. It also took me a while to track it down. That was one of the first records, I think, that I ever sent away for. Eric Clapton did a version on his MTV Unplugged album, and brought that song to a different generation. I found out Bob Dylan, instead with Jesse Fuller, who was a bit of a one-man bandâ¦ he had actually come and played Belfast, but I was too young to go.

Eric Clapton did quite a good version, I must admit, and it turned that song on to anotherâ¦ I never thought Iâd ever be to San Francisco, and there I was, just the other day, last week.

Lauren Martin

Everything comes full circle.

Terri Hooley

That song, going through my head.

Lauren Martin

When it came to, you said, the relationship between your mom and your dad, and your mom took you to Methodist church when you were younger, and youâd be exposed to gospel music, and then you were listening to these things on the radio, how did you think, growing up, that had an impact on your tastes as you became a teenager?

Terri Hooley

I love gospel music. My mom would take me to church on a Sunday morning, to the Sunday school teacher at church. We werenât allowed to play on a Sunday. We had to wear our Sunday best, and we werenât allowed to get anything dirty. Sundays were pretty boring. I do actually love the gospel. I think itâs because of my Methodist upbringing; thereâs a bit of that in me. I like the singing in the churches. That was the bit of church that I like, was the singing. I used to go to Baptist churches, because they used to have tambourines and stuff. I enjoyed that. I remember one night, going to this Baptist hall, and theyâre going, âThereâs a sinner here, thereâs a sinner here,â and had everyone stand. They came up to me and I went, âNo, just totally here for the music,â and never went back.

I like a lot of American gospel music. I like lots of music, but what reallyâ¦ I got a job at the side of city hall, in the photographic exhibition. Music and photography were my great loves. I got to know the reps who would come to the record shop on a Friday, and then that was their last call of the week, and theyâd give me all these free recordsâ¦ demonstration records. I was just in heaven.

I was doing DJingâ¦ I started doing DJing when I was 15, in a youth club, and then I started doing DJ, and then I would have a record, which wasnât released for weeks, and it would be âTerriâs Tip for the Topâ. I can remember, it was like Ike and Tina Turnerâs âRiverâ, Percy Sledge, âWhen a Man Loves a Womanâ. Every week, Iâd have a âTerriâs Tip for the Topâ. It was neverâ¦ âTerriâs Tip for the Topâ was never in the top ten, which was amazing.

Lauren Martin

Very underground of you. I suppose one of the main things that strikes me about you getting into music early on, and feeling an affinity with gospel music, is how that also informed your taste for classic R&B music. Iâve got a track for you, that I was hoping you could tell us a little bit about.

(music: The Shangri-Las - âPast, Present And Futureâ)

Terri Hooley

Yeah.

Lauren Martin

Just when it was getting a bit dramatic.

Terri Hooley

It is the sort of three-minute perfect rock opera. Itâs got âMoonlight Sonataâ, by Beethoven there. Itâs got âA-Tisket, A-Tasketâ, and I love Ella Fitzgeraldâs version. Itâs also like a coffin rock record as well. I was a fanatical Shangri-Las fan, and Ronettes, the Crystals, Supremes, Martha Reeves and the Vandellas; just loved all the girlie groups, the Chiffonsâ¦ donât even start me on the Shirelles.

Lauren Martin

I was hoping to start you.

Terri Hooley

I used to torture my mom to death, especially with the Shangri-Las. My first girlfriend was killed in a car accident coming back from a party in Bangor. The night I was out, painting anti-Vietnam war, slogans around Belfast, and she went to this party, and she was killed on the way back. I used to sit in the bedroom; I just thought Iâd never be with anybody again. My mom used to hear me crying in bed at night. I used to sit in bed, and Iâd play this. I was quite a lonely kid. My brother was a bit nasty, and he wouldnât let me play with anybody he knew and stuff. When I got my own record player, 1/6 [shillings] every week, Kays catalog, Dansette, and I had my own records. I just sort of lived in a sweet world of my own in the bedroom, and the records were my best friends. I was asked, about 40 years ago, what was my all-time favorite record, and I said âItâs âPast, Present and Futureâ by the Shangri-Las. I love that record.â I thought, âThatâs a bit wimpish. It should have been something like âBorn to be Wildâ by Steppenwolf or something.â At that timeâ¦ I would say, if you asked me today, I would say thatâs a very personal record for me, and itâs very part of my growing up.

I was in New York 18 years ago, and somebody told meâ¦ I love George âShadowâ Morton, the producer. He produced the Dixie Cups. He produced a lot of great stuff. Somebody said to me, âHis phone number is in the New York phone book. Why donât you phone him up?â I went, âThatâs a bit like a stalker. I feel a bit bad about it.â

This girl gave me Mary Weissâs, the lead singer of the Shangri-Las, number and said, âWhy donât you phone her up?â I went, âIâm a bit shy.â If anybodyâs seen the story of Good Vibrations, the deal was to get an autographed photograph of the Shangri-Las, and I never got it. Mary Weiss sent me an email one day. David Holmes had got in touch with her, and she sent me an email. I was sitting at home on Friday afternoon, and Mary Weissâ¦ I said, âThat canât be Mary Weiss, the lead singer of the Shangri-Las.â I went and made myself a cup of tea, bit of brandy in it, and I sat there, afraid to open it up. I opened it up, and there was a message from her.

She said, âTerri, what is it you want me to autograph?â I sort of sent her a few lines, then she sent me a few lines, then I told her why I loved the Shangri-Las. I thought, âIâm writing my life story here. Iâd better stop.â We were going to fly Mary Weiss over from New York. Her mother had found, in her loft, an autographed poster of all the bandâ¦ Some of the band are dead. Mary sent it to meâ¦ Sent it to David Holmes, and then we asked her, âWould you come over to Ulster Hall for the opening?â

To tell you the truth, if Mary Weiss had come to Ulster Hall that night, I wouldnât have let her go back to America. Sheâs still not a bad-looking woman, I tell you. I was madly in love with her. I was madly in love with all the Shangri-Las, but I was a big Ronettes fan, and I used to carry, in my pocket, a cut-out of the NME, was a photograph of Ronnie Spector of the Ronettes. Years later, my good friend John T Davis and I were talking one night, and didnât he do exactly the same? He had a cut-out photograph out of a pop magazine, and carried it about when he was a school kidâ¦ another thing that we have in common. Yeah, it was just wonderful. I never even thought Iâd be in correspondence with Mary Weiss. I hope to meet her someday.

Lauren Martin

Thanks very much for sharing that. I appreciate it.

Terri Hooley

She could be a future Mrs Hooley.

Lauren Martin

With any luck. I was also playing that because, like you say in the film Good Vibrations, you agree to pass on your rights, as it were, for the Undertones âTeenage Kicksâ for something like Â£500, a signed photo of the Shangri-Las. I love that, Â£500 will come and go, but a signed photo of the Shangri-Las is forever. I like that saying.

Terri Hooley

People keep asking me. It is a funny thing. I was thinking that I would get some copies made for a few friends, and I went to look for it in the house and I couldnât find it. I know itâs in the room somewhere; I just havenât looked properly. Thereâs this room in the house, and if I set anything down, Claire puts it in the room. I go, âI was reading that letter. What happened to it?â She said, âI put it in the room.â Everythingâs in the room. I know itâs definitely safe but Iâm going to have toâ¦ Thereâs just CDs and records and everything in this room. It needs a good clear-out, but Iâll get to it one of these days.

Lauren Martin

I can imagine thereâs a lot of treasures in there. I was mostlyâ¦

Terri Hooley

Iâd say yeah; ten years ago, I was burned out in a fire, I lost an autographed Johnny Cash photograph that Iâd got from in London. After Johnny died, I took it down, because people wanted to buy it and I said, âNo, Iâm not selling it.â It went up in the fire. Recently, my guys were looking for something else for someone, and then they found an autographed Johnny Cash and June Carter photograph, which I didnât even know I had, so that was a nice surprise.

Lauren Martin

Collecting signed photos was as much as collecting records at this point.

Terri Hooley

I used to be a bit of an autograph hunter; the Kinks, Stones, everybody, when I was younger.

Lauren Martin

I was partly playing that record as well because pop music, and classic American R&B pop music, is such a fine red thread, as it were, throughout the whole feel of Good Vibrations. It was punk rock, but it had a very pop-accessible feel to a lot of things, and I thought the Shangri-Las was a good example of that. It was also really interesting how contemporary black music at the time, from the States, was very much a part of your taste, and that informed what the label went on to become. On that kind of note, Iâm going to play a track, and hopefully it will spark a memory of you from 1968.

(music: Juke Boy Bonner â âBelfast Bluesâ)

Knock it off, Iâve been told.

Terri Hooley

The â60s, to me, were justâ¦ I was born at the right time, in the right place. Iâm 65 now, so I was born in 1940. Just the rock & roll whole thing changed, and then the â60s, and I think the Beatlesâ¦ I was a huge Rolling Stones fanatic. Neverâ¦ I love what the Beatles did, but Iâm not a fanatical Beatles fan, but the Beatles did change everything.

For me as a teenager, growing up in the â60s was absolutely just the most amazing experience in Belfast. Rationing was over. People were starting to have a bit of money. Youth culture was really changing. Everythingâ¦ The music was changing. If you go back and look at the Stones and the Beatles and a lot of bands that were doing covers of American records, and I was the secretaryâ¦ I was running a folk club, a shebeen in the high street, then it sort of closed down, and Dougie Knight asked me if Iâd like to run the blues club in his shop on a Sunday night. Believe it or not, in the â60s, on a Sunday, everything closed down. They used to lock up the swings, so the kids couldnât play. You just couldnât do anything on a Sunday. Weâd run this club on a Sunday night, in his shop. We had maybe five artists on, and it was one and sixpence for girls, and 2/6 for boys, which was my idea. You got free coffee and biscuits and wonderful music.

It was a great promotion for Dougieâs shop, but we also put on concerts, and we brought over a lot of American blues artists. The last concert we ever did was in November, 1968, and thatâs just who you heard, was Juke Boy Bonner. In Belfast, thereâd been trouble, and also there wasnât any rioting that night, but there was a fear of rioting, and the pubs all closed at six oâclock in the evening, and the town was deserted.

We were a bit worried about getting Juke Boy Bonner down from the airport, because weâd heard the roads had been blocked off and stuff. The concert was in the War Memorial building on Waring Street. It was just two minutes away. Itâs a venue, itâs just never used anymore. We were all a bit worried, but the blues crowd came out; we had a good crowd, plus the fact it was the only place in Belfast on Sunday you could get a drink. With the blues crowd and alcoholics, it was a good night.

Lauren Martin

Tomato or tomato, at some point.

Terri Hooley

Weâd done all this food to sell and all; we just gave it away to people. We were waiting to see if Juke Boy Bonner was coming out. We had a friend up on stage playing, and Juke Boy Bonner arrived out. My friend Pauline jumped up and kissed him. It sort of mentions her in the song. I gave him a big hug and was so glad he got such a warm welcome.

That was the night that I realized the party was over, and the â60s was one big party we thought would go on forever. That was the night I realized Bob Dylanâs right; the times, they are aâchanging. That was the start of it. The â70s in this country was horrific. I didnât really do much. We were afraid to go out. Clubs and bars were bombed, and friends had been killed. We stayed at home a lot and were partying in our house. If there was trouble, people just stayed the night. I was sort of selling records from my back bedroom.

It wasnât until I had this job on Howard Street that a friend of mineâ¦ his sister and I had been good friends in the Maritime jazz club, and he was very interested in that period. He came in and he bought a Juke Boy Bonner CD in my shop, and Iâd ordered up all these CDs that were about to be deleted. Iâd ordered them all up. They came up with a copy of Juke Boy Bonner. I remember when we brought him to Belfast he says, âThereâs a track on it called âBelfast Bluesââ. That must be 15 years ago, and I never even knew it existed.

Apparently, Juke Boy Bonner went over to London next week and put it down. I never knew it existed until Colin Carsonâ¦ It was great just to hear that memory. Because my friend Pauline was raped and murdered in New Yorkâ¦ She was my mentor. She was a lot older than me. She taught me to read and write, but she taught me a lot of bad habits, too. I never went back to church after meeting her. I became a right heathen.

She took pity on me, because she thought I was care in the community. Thatâs a three-hour story. I saw this girl one night, she was ten years older than me. I asked to go out with her and she said, âI might see you in the tennis club.â I got all dolled up in my brotherâs teddy boy jacket, which you just didnât wear to dances in those days. I went to the gig, and the girl never turned up.

The speaker said, âAre you trying to be hard man?â I said, âNo, Iâm a pacifist. I donât believe in violence.â I told them the story, and they sort of adopted me and invited me to this barbecue. The next thing, I was drinking Guinness and brandy. They took me to this house, and there was a party on. They asked me what did I want to drink, and I didnât know. All I said was, âIâll have a Babycham,â because that was always on the TV. Pauline just turned around and said, âNo, youâre not. Guinness and porter, thatâs what youâll like.â I had the worst hangover ever. I swore Iâd never drink again.

Lauren Martin

Actually, that recording is called âBelfast Bluesâ, and it was recorded in 1969, so it would have been a year after the gig. It was on his 1970 LP.

Terri Hooley

Where was it recorded?

Lauren Martin

I think it wasâ¦ That was November â68 that he played that gig, so he would have recorded it a couple months later, but it was on a 1970 LP from some London sessions that he did. I picked that partly because you were the secretary of the Blues Society at that time.

Terri Hooley

It was the last gig that we ever did, as the Blues Society. It was the end of a decade for me. The â60s had ended early. It was just a kaleidoscope of color and fashion and freedom. Our Friday night would be, we would go to the Spanish Rooms on the Falls Road, and five or six of us would buy a gallon of cider, and weâd drink it around the entry, and then weâd get 1/6 back on the container, and then weâd buy a pound deal of hashish, and then we would go down to the Maritime Hotel to hear Them. That was just fantastic; one of the greatest bands ever to come out of Belfast, if not the greatest. That was amazing.

Many years later I went back with a couple of â60s musicians to do a bit of filming for The Old Grey Whistle Test, and we couldnât believe how small it was. It was like the size of this room. Our memory of it was, it was like the Ulster Hall. Mervyn Crawfordâ¦ He plays saxophone nowâ¦ He said, âGod, look how tiny that stage is.â My legs were shaking going up. We just couldnâtâ¦ It was like somebody had built a wee facsimile of it. Our memory of it was that it was huge, but it wasnât. It was just like this room, basically, maybe a bit bigger.

That was fantastic. That was a fantastic club. There were 80 clubs in and around Belfast where you could hear live music â unbelievable. When the Troubles came, there were like twoâ¦ The weekends were just bonkers. You just didnât get any sleep. The â60s was likeâ¦

Lauren Martin

Speaking of Them, I was also, with the âBelfast Bluesâ track, again talking about the influence of things like the Shangri-Las, the influence of contemporary black pop and R&B music on the sound. I think when youâre saying the end of the â60s was like a massive social, political, but also a cultural cut-off point, when Belfast really became very insular, mostly not of its own volition. I thought I could play parts of 2 tracks, just to kind of exemplify the influence of R&B on what was happening in Belfast.

(music: Rudi â âBig Timeâ)

Lauren Martin

It seems a shame to cut off in the middle of a riff, but that was âBig Timeâ by Rudi.

Terri Hooley

I donât know whether it was those speakers or what, but it sounded really good to me.

Lauren Martin

Itâs possibly difficult for somebody of my age group to understand hearing punk, anthologized as it has become, but in the context of Belfast, at the time, there was basically a ghettoization of the city â bars were shutting at tea time. There were no venues open, and there were quite literally barricades.

Terri Hooley

Yes, a ring of steel around the city center.

Lauren Martin

A ring of steel around the city center. I was listening to a really interesting BBC Radio 4 interview with a woman recently, who claims to be one of these punks. She said it was essentially a violent playground, between the punks, the RUC, and the army.

Terri Hooley

Yes.

Lauren Martin

I remember yourself saying that the punks basically saved Belfast.

Terri Hooley

They opened up the night life again in Belfast. Jim Cusack, who was the security correspondent for The Irish Times, knew quite a lot, and from Belfastâ¦ He said, âIt was Terri Hooley and the punks that opened up the nightlife in Belfast.â Iâm not completely sure that was true, but we certainly did help. Where we are, in this areaâ¦ the Harp Bar was just around the corner, which was a shithole, basically. It was a strip club during the day, and they had music at night. We opened up the Harp Bar, and it really was the first time in a decade where kidsâ¦ whether they were Protestant or Catholic, it didnât matter. If your hair was orange or green, it didnât matter if you came from Mars, as long as you were a punk. Not all punks were love and peace; far from it. There were some right bastards.

A lot of people said to me, âIf it wasnât for the punk and all, we would have joined the paramilitaries. We would have killed people. We would have ended up in jail.â It changed a lot of peopleâs lives, not only my own, but also a lot of the bands, like Stiff Little Fingers, the Undertones. It was just a time of no hope, and punk, to me, was like a little candle; a little light in the darkness, in this sea of madness and sectarian violence and craziness. It was also very exciting. It was really, really exciting.
